e4: While the new policy would eliminate bias in reporting, it could lead to unexpected market reactions and potentially harm small investors who have historically been able to anticipate the adjustment. On the other hand, the current policy has been well-established for years and is understood by most investors, including sophisticated hedge funds. Before changing the policy, I would want to ensure that the company can effectively communicate the change and mitigate any potential negative impacts on retail investors.
e5: A reporting policy is viewed ethically when it prioritizes transparency, accuracy, and fairness. It should clearly disclose any material adjustments or biases that may impact investor understanding. Additionally, the policy should consider the interests of all stakeholders, including retail investors, hedge funds, and smaller investors who may be most vulnerable to market fluctuations. Ethical reporting policies also promote trust and credibility, allowing investors to make informed decisions based on reliable data. Finally, policies that prioritize clarity, consistency, and adaptability to change are generally viewed as more ethical than those that prioritize short-term gains or special interests.
e6: Yes, I would have follow-up questions for the management team regarding their plans to ensure a smooth transition to the new policy, including how they will communicate the change to retail investors and other stakeholders, and what measures they will take to mitigate potential market volatility. Additionally, I would like to understand the potential benefits of the new policy in terms of financial reporting accuracy and investor trust.
